item.title: Ph.D in Computer Science
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
[columns width="1/4"] [/columns] [columns width="3/4" last="true"]

Universidad AutÃ³noma de Madrid - July 2011

[list]
  • Area: Computational Neuroscience
  • Topic: Hierarchical Temporal Memory
[/list] [toggle type="3" title="
Details
"] [box type="blank" class="border-dashed2"] During my Ph.D I have studiedÂ  a connectionist machine learning algorithm known as Hierarchical Temporal Memory, or HTM. HTM is bioinspired on some of the working principles employed by the neocortex to create invariance, namely spatio-temporal coding and a hierarchical topology of learning units or nodes.Â  Particularly, I have explored the optimization of HTM algorithms to spatio-temporal patterns that slowly unfold over time. For this purpose, I have created a customized top-node that employs sequence alignment using dynamic programming to cluster sequences according to their similarity.Â  I have successfully implemented my approach on the automatic recognition of sign language and on a new paradigm of eye tracking interaction: gaze gestures. My doctoral period has been very fruitful and enriching thanks in part to the flexibility and support of my two Ph.D thesis advisers who have allowed me to explore research directions in areas not originally intended in my thesis proposal.Â  For this, I'm very grateful to both of them: Pablo Varona and Francisco de Borja Rodriguez. During the course of my Ph.D, I have published and presented my work in peer review journals and international conferences. I have also taken graduate level courses in: Neuroanatomy, Cognitive Psychology, Multi-variable Statistics, Neural Networks and Computational Neuroscience. I have also carried out two research visits to the Gaze Group at the IT University of Copenhagen and to the Institute for Science, Innovation and Society at Oxford University. [/box] [/toggle] [/columns]

item.title: M.Sc. in Bioinformatics
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
[columns width="1/4"] [/columns] [columns width="3/4" last="true"]

Freie UniversitÃ¤t Berlin - Sept 2005

[list]
  • Topic 1: Biological Networks
  • Topic 2: Data Analysis
  • Grades: Average 1.4 (max:1, min:4)
[/list] [toggle type="3" title="
Details
"] [box type="blank" class="border-dashed2"] I studied bioinformatics at one of the first German universities that introduced a degree in this budding field.Â  During my Master I took classes in a wide array of areas: Computer Programming, Biological Networks, Data Analysis, Signal Pathways, Cognitive Neuroscience, Data Structures, Algorithms and Computational Mathematics.Â  I carried out my master's thesis on the selection of genetic sequences for the transcriptoma-wide mapping project known as EURexpress at the Max Planck Institute for Molecular Genetics under the supervision of Prof. Dr. Hans Lehrach. [/box] [/toggle] [/columns]

item.title: About Me
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
First Steps

I was born in Gijon, a medium size city in the north coast of Spain. As I child, my family and I moved around the country quite a bit, so I ended up growing up in several cities: Oviedo, Salamanca, Avila, Orense, Leon and Madrid. Besides that much moving around, my childhood was pretty much unremarkable: attending school, doing sports and playing around consumed most of my time. Looking back at that period and doing some reflection, I realize now I enjoyed a pretty good time during childhood =)

Swimming

As a teenager and during early adulthood, I became very involved with swimming. During that time, I was very focused on the pool and a bit rebellious in school. Good coaches, plenty of motivation and long training sessions, managed to get me some successes in the swimming pool: I was national champion in 200 fly, silver medalist in 400 freestyle and represented my country in the international arena at European Swimming Championships and the Paris Swimming World Cup of 97. I also managed to make the ranking of the 50 fastest swimmers in the world in 1500 free, 400 free and 200 fly. As a result of it all, I got several offers for full scholarships at American universities to join their swimming team. I ended up attending the University of Tennessee, Knoxville, but after one year of poor swimming performance, I transferred to Boston University where I completed my undergraduate degree. While at Boston, I managed to get back in form by winning the award to the most outstanding swimmer of the America East Conference in 2002 and several accolades as a scholar athlete including 3 MVPs during the seasonâs 2000, 2001 and 2002. Besides competitive swimming, one of the best things about my varsity sport experience was the comradeship spirit that we developed within the BU team. I still treasure very much the friendships and memories from those years.

College Years and USA

While at Boston, I obtained my Bachelorâs Degree in Business Administration at Boston University concentrating in Management of Information Systems. Around that time, I became interested on recent advances in genetics. This wasÂ  due in part to all the fuss generated around the sequencing and mapping of the human genome and the subsequent dual publications in both Science and Nature journals of the public and private teams results. Thanks to the flexibility of the American higher education system, I was able to pursue a Minor in Molecular Biology along with my Bachelors in Business Administration. I really enjoyed my time as a college student in the United States. IÂ  still carry with me very positive memories from those years and the opportunities they provided me with. American mentality and optimism, stimulating college professors, the international environment of university campuses and courses content in a variety of subjects enriched and broadened my perspective tremendously. Although I very much enjoyed my education in Boston in a soft science such as Management, I was eager to learn more about Computer Science and Molecular Biology. I also wanted to get to know a country in Europe different of my own. A perfect fit to align all those objectives was to pursue a Masterâs degree in Bioinformatics at the Freie UniversitÃ¤t Berlin, one of the first universities in Germany to offer such an interdisciplinary degree.

Germany

The first months in Berlin were hard. The German language proved tough to master, the German economy was in a recession and I needed to find a job to fund my studies and living expenses. It was a hard time but after many unsuccessful job interviews, I ended up working as a waiter for a while. Although the salary was bellow minimum wage, some good things came out of it: I learned to prepare a few good cocktails, met some interesting people and the job provided me with the opportunity to improve my German. Eventually, it helped me to land a better job at the University library as a computer technician. One of the best things about my time in Germany was the people I lived with in a Wohngemeinschaft, a couple formed by Wolfgang and Linda, and its two daughters, Laura and Elena. Though very different in the way we perceived and understood the world, I shared wonderful conversations and experiences with them. During that period, they acted and truly felt to me almost as a second family. Meanwhile, graduate courses at the university were kicking my butt, but I enjoyed the opportunity to learn about neuroinformatics, systems biology, biological networks, neuroscience, proteomics and data analysis algorithms. Thanks to a twist of luck, I started working at the Max Planck Institute for Molecular Genetics, under the supervision of Prof. Dr. Hans Lehrach, doing bioinformatics stuff: exon splicing site detection, and selection of ESTs for a multinational gene expression project known as the EURexpress Atlas.

Ph. D

After completing my Master, I decided to pursue a Ph.D in Computer Science in my home country at Universidad AutÃ³noma de Madrid. The topic of my dissertation was a Bayesian algorithm inspired on neocortical principles of information processing known as Hierarchical Temporal Memory or HTM. HTMs use a number of organizational and information coding principles from the neocortex to carry out pattern recognition. My small addition to the algorithm was an extension that optimizes its performance for a particular set of problems: those with a spatio-temporal structure slowly unfolding over time. During my Ph.D, I continued taking graduate courses in several disciplines related on one way or another to my work: neuroscience, machine learning, computational neuroscience and psychology. I also carried out some brief stints in the Innovative Communication group at the IT University of Copenhagen doing Eye Tracking research and at the Institute for Science Innovation and Society at Oxford University. Both visits were very enriching both in terms of the research carried out and also at the personal level by getting to know some of the very interesting people working there. My Ph.D thesis advisors have been Universidad AutÃ³noma Professors' Pablo Varona and Franciso de Borja Rodriguez. Working with Pablo and Paco has been a great experience. Their knowledge, unshattered support, enthusiasm about science, work ethics, comprehension about my limitations and the freedom they provided me in choosing my own research path astonished me continuously during my doctoral years and made me very grateful. Using soft management and leading by example, Pablo and Paco have managed to create an easy going and yet productive and innovation-fostering atmosphere within the Neurocomputation Group, which is not an easy task given the inherently competitive nature of academia.

Postdoc... Australia...

My postdoctoral period has took me and my significant other to the southern hemisphere... and specifically into a country I always wanted to get to know better: Australia. I joined CSIRO on January 2012 and so far I'm loving it. CSIRO, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization, is Australia's national science agency on one of the largest and most diverse research agencies in the world. I am specifically located at CSIRO's Queensland Center for Advanced Technologies (QCAT), Australia's largest integrated research and development precint for the resources and associated advanced technology industries. QCATÂ provides a synergistic environment for groundbreaking research, innovation and technology development between research providers, government institutions and industry. During my time here, I'll be working on the topics of DNA origami, eye tracking an HTMs.  

Personal

On a more personal level, some of the things I enjoy the most are debating about ideas with interesting people, reading the works of people knowledgeable on their field, watching stand up comedy and hanging out with dogs. For me, a frank and rational interchange of thoughts and ideas between people with different viewpoints is an activity that enriches both parts involved and Iâm always willing to engage in one. About reading, I very much like reading the work of people with insightful perspectives in their own subject of specialization. In terms of stand up comedians, I admire the creativity (of some of them) to cleverly play with words, stereotypes and to stretch the boundaries of political correctness in a funny tone. In terms of dogs, I do hope that in the not so distant future, when circumstances are right, I'll be able to have my own dog since, for me, they provide a world of joy.

item.title: Frontpage2
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Background and Research Interests

  • Postdoctoral Fellow: Autonomous Systems Lab - CSIRO, Australia
  • Ph.D in Computer Science: Universidad AutÃ³noma de Madrid
  • M.Sc. in Bioinformatics: Freie UniversitÃ¤t Berlin
  • B.Sc in Business Information Systems: Boston University
  • Previous Posts: Teaching Assistant at Universidad AutÃ³noma de Madrid,Â Assistant Researcher: Max Planck Institute - Molgen
  • Languages: Spanish, English and German
  • Research Interests: Brain Computer Interfaces, Human Computer Interaction, Machine Learning, Gaze Tracking
  • Visiting Scholar: Oxford University, IT University of Copenhaguen, Tohoku University,Â Harvard University

item.title: Publications
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
One of the main purposes of a career in academia is the creation and dissemination of knowledge.Â  Here is a list of selected publications I have produced during the last years: Peer Reviewed Journals: [J1] Graciana Diez-Roux, Sandro Banfi, Marc Sultan, Lars Geffers, Santosh Anand, David Rozado, Alon Magen, ElenaÂ Canidio, Massimiliano Pagani, Ivana Peluso, et al. A high- resolution anatomical atlas of the transcriptome in theÂ mouse embryo. PLoS biology, 9(1):e1000582, 2011. [J2] David Rozado, Francisco B Rodriguez, and Pablo Varona.Â Extending the bioinspired hierarchical temporal memoryÂ paradigm for sign language recognition. Neurocomputing, 2011. [J3] David Rozado, Javier San Agustin, Francisco Rodriguez,Â and Pablo Varona. Gliding and saccadic gaze gesture recognition in real time. ACM Transactions on Intelligent Interactive Systems, 2011. [J4] David Rozado, Francisco B Rodriguez, and Pablo Varona.Â Low cost remote gaze gesture recognition in real time. Applied Soft Computing, 12(8):2072â2084, 2012. [J5] D Rozado, T Moreno, J San Agustin, FB Rodriguez, andÂ P Varona. Controlling a smartphone using gaze gesturesÂ as the input mechanism. Human-Computer Interaction,Â (just-accepted), 2013. [J6] David Rozado. Mouse and keyboard cursor warping toÂ accelerate and reduce the effort of routine HCI inputÂ tasks. Human-Machine Systems, IEEE Transactions on, 43(5):487â493, 2013. Â 

Â Publications in international conferences and LNCS/LNAI series: [C1] David Rozado, Francisco Rodriguez, and Pablo Varona.Â Optimizing hierarchical temporal memory for multivariable time series. In Artificial Neural Networks (ICANN)Â 2010, pages 506â518, 2010. [C2] David Rozado, Francisco Rodriguez, and Pablo Varona.Â Gaze gesture recognition with hierarchical temporal memory networks. In Advances in Computational Intelligence,Â pages 1â8, 2011. [C3] Jeremy Hales, David Rozado, and Diako Mardanbegi. Interacting with objects in the environment by gaze andÂ hand gestures. Lund, Sweden., 2013. [C4] David Rozado, Belinda Ward, and Fred Pauling. Distributed eye tracking network for conveying gaze of remoteÂ users in a robotic telepresence scenario. Lund, Sweden,Â 2013. [C5] David Rozado. Using gaze based passwords as an authentication mechanism for password input. In 3rd InternationalÂ Workshop on Pervasive Eye Tracking and Mobile Eye-Based Interaction. Lund, Swedem, Lund, Sweden, 2013. [C6] Karlos Ishac and David Rozado. Low cost human-robotÂ gaze estimation system. In ACM International ConferenceÂ Proceedings, 2014. [C7] Matheus Portela and David Rozado. Gaze enhancedÂ speech recognition for truly hands-free and ecient textÂ input during HCI. In OzCHI2014, Sydney, 2014. ACM. [C8] Louis Stephen and David Rozado. Interacting with objectsÂ in the environment using gaze tracking glasses and speech.Â In OzCHI2014, Sydney, 2014. ACM. Â  Ph.D Thesis: Analysis and Extension of Hierarchical Temporal Memory for Multivariable Time Series. Thesis supervised by: Prof. Pablo Varona and Prof. Francisco de Borja. Escuela PolitÃ©cnica Superior - Universidad AutÃ³noma de Madrid.

Â Master Thesis: Selection of transcript-representative clones for template generation in the EURexpress transcriptome-wide gene expression study. Thesis supervised by: Prof. Dr. Hans Lehrach and Dr. Marie-Laure Yaspo. Fachbereich Mathematik und Informatik - Freie UniversitÃ¤t Berlin.

item.title: Teaching
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
A core aspect of a work in academia is the transmission of knowledge. Â One of the things I enjoy the most about my job is the opportunity to teach others.Â  During the last years, I have taught both conventional lectures and course labs. I have also supervised numerous students during their Bachelor/Master Thesis projects or during internships. Â The following is a list of courses that I have taught and students that I have supervised: UNIVERSITY COURSES TAUGHT: Human Computer InteractionÂ -Â University of Tasmania (2014):Â Course for 3rdÂ and final year undergraduate students, and also postgraduates. Â This course introduces students to the theory and practice of developing user interfaces. Practical concerns are balanced by discussion of relevant theory from the literature of computer science (graphics, software engineering, multimedia), cognitive psychology, and industrial design. Students who take this class will (a) develop practical user interface design skills, (b) develop an understanding of the human side of computing, (c) understand the significance of historical case studies, (d) learn about future directions in HCI.Â  Wireless Sensor NetworksÂ -Â The University of Queensland (2013):Â Course for 3rdÂ and final year undergraduate students, and also postgraduates.Â Â A variety of topics in the field of Sensor Networks is covered: sensors, actuators, storage and debugging, IPv6 routing, TCP/UDP, localization, mobility tracking, time synchronization, sensing for health applications, multimedia sensor networks, energy efficiency.Â This course is a combination of lectures and group project work: lab projects, a final project demo, a final project presentation. Wireless Sensor NetworksÂ -Â The University of Queensland (2012):Â Course for 3rdÂ and final year undergraduate students, and also postgraduates.Â Â A variety of topics in the field of Sensor Networks is covered: sensors, actuators, storage and debugging, IPv6 routing, TCP/UDP, localization, mobility tracking, time synchronization, sensing for health applications, multimedia sensor networks, energy efficiency.Â This course is a combination of lectures and group project work: lab projects, a final project demo, a final project presentation. Introduction to computer science -Â Universidad AutÃ³noma de Madrid (2009-2010): An undergraduate course in the school of engineering at Universidad AutÃ³noma de Madrid.Â  The course is a crash course on the MATLAB environment and the corresponding programming language paradigm.Â  The course covers topics about: data structures, flow control, functions, recursive functions, input/output and algorithms.

Fundamentals of informatics - Universidad AutÃ³noma de Madrid (2008-2009): An undergraduate course offered by the school of computer science at Universidad AutÃ³noma de Madrid.Â  The course is an overview of fundamental concepts about computer science.Â  The topics covered are: hardware and software, digital representation of information, operating systems and introduction to programming.

NON-UNIVERSITY COURSES: I taught the following courses at several social centers in the city of Madrid during November 2005 and February 2007. Conversational English: Advanced course about conversational skills on the English language. English for children: Introductory course to the English language for children.Â  Emphasis placed on learning by playing. Introductory English for adults: Introductory course to the English language for adults with little or no formal educational background. Introductory German: Crash course on the basis of the German language. Introduction to IT: Computer literacy course for adults.

item.title: Research
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Intro

I am interested in the interaction between humans and technology in a multidisciplinary sense. In the next lines, I provide a brief summary of what I have been doing in terms of research during the last years.

Exon Splicing Detection in Chimp Genome

My first steps as a researcher took place at the Max Planck Institute for Molecular Genetics in Berlin (MPI Molgen) where I worked part-time as a Bioinformatician while doing my Masters at the nearby Freie UniversitÃ¤t Berlin. My first assignment at MPI Molgen was to work on the automatic recognition of Exon Splicing Enhancers (ESEs) sequences in the chimp genome. ESEs are interesting for genomic research since they are able to attract protein complexes that stimulate exon inclussion during gene transcription in the gene regions they occupy. For this task, I developed a combination of matrix-based approaches to make heuristic predictions about potential ESEs candidates sites using data from previously con firmed ESEs sites in the human genome. My second project at the MPI Molgen was the development of a simple Java application to visualize gene expression data from the mouse genome. The data was gathered using in situ hybridization at several time points during embryonic development.

Gene Selection from a EST clone Database

The most important project I worked on while at the Max Planck Institute was the Eurexpress project.Â  Eurexpress is aÂ  multinational consortium to determine the expression patterns of the whole genome of a mouse embryo at day 14.5 of embryonic development. The gene expression data is gathered through automatic high throughput in situ hybridization. Ascertaining when and where genes are expressed is of crucial importance in order to understand the physiological role of a given gene/protein and the interactions between them. Additionally, normal expression patterns can then be compared to those observed in a variety of pathological conditions to identify pathological hallmarks of gene expression. The EURExpress was a EU funded project under the VI Framework. It proposed a transcriptome-wide acquisition of expression patterns by means of in situ hybridization (ISH) with non-radioactive probes and used the data to establish a web-linked, interactive digital transcriptome atlas of embryonic mouse.Â  This data resulted in a detailed description (at a cellular level) of gene expression patterns in the developing mouse. My task on the project consisted on designing an algorithm to select ESTs (Expressed Sequence Tags) from a clone database of DNA sequences. The selected ESTs were then used to do the mRNA "fishing" of the > 20,000 genes through in-situ hybridization on sagittal sections from E14.5 wild type murine embryos.

Machine Learning using Hierarchical Temporal Memory

During my Ph.D,Â  I have worked on a machine learning algorithm known as Hierarchical Temporal Memory (HTM). HTM is inspired on some principles extracted from neuroscientific research about neocortical function, namely a hierarchical organization and spatio-temporal coding. During the first stages of my Ph.D, I formalized HTM theory in my own algorithmic implementation of HTM. I tested as a proof of principle this in-house version on a simple data set of two dimensional images. Results were good and encouraged me to further explore the algorithm. One area where I noticed HTMs required optimization was on a set of problems were instances slowly unfold over time. I created an extension of the HTM algorithm to handle this type of problems by modifying the top node of a connectionist network and making it store sequences of spatio-temporal patterns composing the instance to be learned and clustering them according to a similarity metric obtained from sequence alignment through dynamic programming (a technique I borrowed from bioinformatics).

Low cost Eye Tracking, Pupillometry and Gaze Gestures

During the equator of my Ph.D, I started to explore a new paradigm of human computer interaction: gaze tracking.Â  I began a collaboration with the Gaze Group at the IT University of Copenhagen. They were working on a project to make a low cost eye tracker using off the shelf components.Â  An acute problem of gaze interaction is the Midas touch problem, i.e. the difficulty for a gaze aware system to distinguish users intentions when looking at an object in terms of whether the user is trying to trigger a command on the object or just inspecting it.Â  Gaze interaction traditionally deals with this problem by means of dwell time selection or usage of an external switch.Â  This solution is not satisfactory for certain types of users with motor disabilities or in certain environments.Â  To tackle this problem, I explored the usage of an innovative approach to gaze interaction, namely, the usage of gaze gestures.Â  I successfully applied my extension of the HTM algorithms to the recognition of gaze gestures successfully distinguishing them from otherwise normal computer gaze interaction, see link. During this time I also wrote a piece of software to monitor pupil diameter while a user interacts with a computer. Pupil diameter is interesting from a Psychophisiology point of view since pupil size has been connected to emotional responses. This is mediated by the Autonomic Nervous System that innervates circular and radial pupil fibers for contraction and dilation through its parasympathetic and sympathetic subsystems. Additionally, I also worked on thisÂ project to interact with a smartphone through gaze.

DNA Origami

My first project as a postdoc at CSIRO will be on the exciting topic of DNA origami.Â DNA origami is the nanoscale folding of DNA to create arbitrary two and three dimensional shapes at the nanoscale. The specificity of the interactions between complementary base pairs make DNA a useful construction material, through design of its base sequences. Developed by Paul Rothemund at the California Institute of Technology, the process involves the folding of a long single strand of viral DNA aided by multiple smaller "staple" strands. These shorter strands bind the longer in various places, resulting in two-dimensional shapes or more complex three-dimensional structures. I have developed a plugin for the leading DNA Origami design software, caDNAno.Â My plugin,Â expands the functionality of caDNAno by providing visual feedback to the DNA origami designer by color coding each staple strand according to a gradient that codifies the melting temperature (Tm) of each staple strand in a given shape. In this way the designer can optimize the design by situation strands with high melting temperature at the core of the shape and strands with lower melting temperature on the outer surface of the shape to improve the yield during the assembly process.  

Robotic Telepresence and Eye Tracking Networks

Project from CSIRO to develop a technology that will allow remote visitors to 'visit' a museum using a semi-autonomous mobile robot and anÂ immerseÂ web interface (krpano engine), more information available here. The system is designedÂ to allow remote visitors to feel as though they are on an actual tour in the museum. The host museum is theÂ Landmarks Gallery of theÂ National Museum of Australia and will involve students from schools across Australia.Â My task in this project will be construction of a network of low cost eye trackers that will allow monitoring remote students gaze while visiting the museum. This technology can enableÂ handicappedÂ students to visit the museum through gaze interaction and also to study how students interact and learn during the visit. The aggregated gaze activity of the remote students is displayed in a wide field of view panoramic image of the scene by the robot to provide visual feedback to the museum tour guide about where students are paying attention to.  

Augmented HCI and Gaze Tracking Glasses

I have recently worked on several projects to augment Human-Computer Interaction through the use of eye tracking such as input of passwords in a computer through gaze and on software that monitors gazeÂ subtlyÂ behind the scenes to augment and speed up text editing, web browsing and mouse acquisition tasks in GUIs. See link1 and link2 for illustration purposes. I built a set of low cost wireless mobile gaze tracking glasses for innovative interaction with objects in the environment through a collaboration with a world leading researcher in the field of mobile gaze tracking, Diako MardanbegiÂ at the IT University of Copenhagen, author of the HaythamÂ open sourceÂ software. I am also currently exploring the usage of eye tracking for rehabilitation purposes in patients with traumatic brain injury and the usage of video based face tracking and low cost EEG in combination with gaze tracking to monitor computer user's cognitive status.

Optimizing a Brain Computer Interface Using Pupil Diameter

For individuals with high degrees of motor disability or locked-in syndrome, it is impractical or impossible to use mechanical switches to interact with electronic devices. Brain computer interfaces (BCIs) can use motor imagery to detect interaction intention from users but lack the accuracy of mechanical switches. Â Hence, there exists a strong need Â to improve the accuracy of Â EEG-based motor imagery BCIs attempting to implement an on/off switch. We have investigated how Â monitoring the pupil diameter of a person as a psycho-physiological parameter in addition to traditional EEG channels can improve the classification accuracy of a switch-like BCI. We have recently noticed in our lab how motor imagery is associated with increases in pupil diameter when compared to a control rest condition. The pupil diameter parameter is easily accessible through video oculography since most gaze tracking systems report pupil diameter invariant to head position. We used common spatial patterns to separate motor imagery, signaling movement intention, from a rest control condition. By monitoring the pupil diameter of the user and using this parameter as an additional feature, we show that the performance of the classifier trying to discriminate motor imagery from a control condition improves over the traditional approach using just Â EEG derived features. Given the limitations Â of EEG Â to construct highly robust and reliable BCIs, Â we postulate that multi-modal approaches, such as the one presented here that monitor several psycho-physiological parameters, can be a successful strategy in making BCIs more accurate and less vulnerable to constraints such as requirements for long training sessions or high signal to noise ratio of electrode channels.

EEG-based Motor Imagery for Upper Arm Rehabilitation

Currently I am working on building an EEG-based motor imagery brain computer interface for rehabilitation of upper extremity paralysis using a thought-driven exoskeleton. Primary sensory- motor cortical areas exhibit rhythmic activity at a frequency of approximately 8-12 Hz when they are not processing sensory information or producing motor output. This activity is called mu rhythm. Â Movement or preparation for movement is typically accompanied by a decrease in mu activity over sensorimotor cortex. This decrease has been labeled "event-related desynchronization" or ERD. This ERD occur also with motor imagery do not requiring actual movement. Hence, they can occur independent of activity in the brain's normal output channels of peripheral nerves and muscles, and could serve as the basis for a BCI driven rehabilitation platform. The tools I am using for data analysis and signal processing areÂ EEGLABÂ andÂ BCILAB.Â Additionally,Â I am alsoÂ using real time pupil size monitoring for assessment of cognitive load during different tasks.  

Interacting with a Computer Using Gaze and Face Gestures

Together with University of Tasmania student Jason Niu, we have created the Face Switch, An open-source application that allows a user to control a computer using face gestures such as: open mouth, raised eyebrows, nose twitch or smile. The gestures are monitored in a contactless manner using a face tracker (Beyond Reality Face SDK). The Face SwitchÂ accessibility software when used in combination with a gaze tracker, provides motor disabled users the possibility of interacting with a computer almost as fast as someone using a traditional mouse. Check it out at:Â https://github.com/Jason-NIU/Face-switch.Â The Face Switch is an application that transforms predefined facial gestures to specific keyboard keystrokes. The program can help computer users with limited mobility from the neck down but who have a good level of control of facial muscles. The software is intended to be used in combination with the Tobii PCEye Go eye trackerÂ Â and Tobii's accessibility software for computer controlled through gaze: Tobii Gaze Interaction Software 2.6.2.

item.title: B.Sc. in Business Administration
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
[columns width="1/4"] [/columns] [columns width="3/4" last="true"]

Boston University - May 2002

[list]
  • Concentration: Information Systems
  • Minor: Molecular Biology
  • GPA: 3.38/4 (Cum Laude)
[/list] [toggle type="3" title="
Details
"] [box type="blank" class="border-dashed2"] I completed my undergraduate degree in Business Administration. The degree consisted of the traditional set of courses: Financial Accounting, Managerial Accounting, Mathematical Finance, Management as a System, Marketing, Operations Management, Managerial Statistics, Business Law, Human Resources, Information Systems Management and Strategic Planning.Â  I specialized in the sub-field of Management of Information Systems by taking classes in: Database Administration and Design, Object Oriented Programming, C++ Programming, Network Architecture and Systems Design.Â  Due to my increasing interest in Bioinformatics, I also got a minor in molecular biology, taking classes in: Cell Biology, Molecular Biology, Genetics, Biochemistry, Organic Chemistry and Bioinformatics. [/box] [/toggle] [/columns]

item.title: Computer Lab Supervisor
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
[columns width="1/4"] [/columns] [columns width="3/4" last="true"] November 1999-May 2002 BU School of Management [list]
  • Assist users with computer related issues
  • Monitor network issues
[/list] [toggle type="3" title="
Details
"] [box type="blank"] Partial time job consisting on supporting users on a university computer lab and do some network administration stuff. [/box] [/toggle] [/columns]

item.title: Network Support Staff
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
[columns width="1/4"] [/columns] [columns width="3/4" last="true"] November 2002-November 2003 FUB - UniversitÃ¤tsbibliothek [list]
  • Assist library staff with computer/network related issues
  • Writing scripts to support Library's Database Administration
[/list] [toggle type="3" title="
Details
"] [box type="blank"] Partial time job consisting on supporting the staff of the University Library on computer/network/databases related issues. I also performed some small scripts writing (Perl, PHP) to monitor smooth operations of library's database. [/box] [/toggle] [/columns]

item.title: Graduate Assistant Researcher
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
[columns width="1/4"] [/columns] [columns width="3/4" last="true"] November 2003-November 2005 Max Planck Institute for Molecular Genetics [list]
  • Software Development / Data Analysis
  • Selection of over 10,000 transcript representative clones for the EURexpress project
  • Developed software for in-silico detection of Exon Splic- ing Enhancers in human genome
  • Developed software for visualization of Chromosome 21 gene expression patterns in mouse
[/list] [toggle type="3" title="
Details
"] [box type="blank"] I carried out several tasks during my two years stint at MPI Molgen working at the department of vertebrate genomics led by Prof. Dr. Hans Lehrach. I wrote software for identification of Exon Splicing Enhancers in the Chimp genome. I also wrote software in Java to visualize temporal patterns of gene expression on a mouse embryo using data coming from in-situ hybridization experiments. My most important job was implementing an algorithm to select Expressed Sequence Tags (ESTs) from a Database of mouse ESTs in order for them to be used in an international project consortium to map the whole genome expression pattern of mice during embryonic development. The results of this work are available to the scientific community at http://www.eurexpress.org. This project also led to a PLoS Biology article A High-Resolution Anatomical Atlas of the Transcriptome in the Mouse Embryo [/box] [/toggle] [/columns]

item.title: Professor of Social Center School
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
[columns width="1/4"] [/columns] [columns width="3/4" last="true"] November 2005-February 2007 Tritoma Social Centers [list]
  • Professor of English, German, and Informatics
[/list] [toggle type="3" title="
Details
"] [box type="blank"] Job consisting on teaching courses with a low content load on different subjects: English, German and Introduction to Informatics. Some of the courses were oriented to adults with University education while others targeted specifically adults with no higher education background. Others courses were oriented toward children. The diverse set of students made necessary to prepare curricular adjustments for each individual case. [/box] [/toggle] [/columns]

item.title: Research and Teaching Graduate Assistant
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
[columns width="1/4"] [/columns] [columns width="3/4" last="true"] February 2007-March 2011 Universidad Autonoma de Madrid [list]
  • Carry out research tasks for my Ph.D thesis on the topic of Hierarchical Temporal Memory (HTM), a bioinspired pattern recognition algorithm.
  • Development of software with the HTM framework for image recognition, sign language recognition and gaze gestures recognition within the realm of video-based eye tracking.
  • Teaching: - Introduction to Computer Science - Fundamentals of Informatics
[/list] [toggle type="3" title="
Details
"] [box type="blank"] During my Ph.D, I have carried out an extension of the Hierarchical Temporal Memory paradigm for problems where instances unfold slowly over time. I have successfully applied my extension to the problems of sign language recognition and gaze gesture recognition. The results of this work have been published in peer reviewed journals and international conferences. As part of my Ph.D duties, I have also been a teaching assistant for two introductory classes to computer science for engineers. I was also elected to the governing organ of the school as a representative of research and teaching assistants. Additionally I have carried out research visits to the IT University of Copenhagen and to Oxford University. [/box] [/toggle] [/columns]

item.title: Postdoctoral Fellow
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
[columns width="1/4"] [/columns] [columns width="3/4" last="true"] January 2012 - Ongoing Autonomous Systems Lab - CSIRO [list]
  • Development of EEG-based Brain Computer Interface for motor rehabilitation using an exoskeleton
  • Usage of pupillometry for cognitive load assessment
  • Development of eye tracking network software for robotic telepresence
  • Work on several projects for augmented Human Computer Interaction through Gaze Interaction
  • Build a prototype of low cost wireless Gaze Tracking Glasses
  • Carry out research on optimization of DNA Origami Folding
[/list] [toggle type="3" title="
Details
"] [box type="blank"] [list]
  • Building an EEG-based motor imagery brain computer interface for rehabilitation of upper extremity paralysis using a thought-driven exoskeleton
  • Usage of real time pupil size monitoring for assessment of cognitive load
  • Eye Tracker Network: Building up aÂ network of low cost eye trackers to streamÂ data about the gaze behaviour of several computer usersÂ simultaneously
  • Â Museum Robot Telepresence: Using the aforementionedÂ Eye Tracker Network to capture the gaze behavior of severalÂ remote visitors to a museum. Providing this informationÂ superimposed on a panoramic image as feedbackÂ to the museum tour guide interacting with the robot
  • Augmented HCI using Eye Tracking: to speed up routineÂ HCI input task such as target acquisition, text editing, text selection and drag and drop operations
  • Wireless Eye Tracking Glasses: for innovative interactionÂ with objects in the environment
  • Optimization of Algorithms for DNA Origami Design using caDNAno: Creating a plugin for the DNA Origami design software caDNAno. My plugin,Â expands the functionality of caDNAno by providing visual feedback to the DNA origami designer by color coding each staple strand according to a gradient that codifies the melting temperature (Tm) of each staple strand in a given shape. In this way the designer can optimize the design by situation strands with high melting temperature at the core of the shape and strands with lower melting temperature on the outer surface of the shape to improve the yield during the assembly process.
[/list] [/box] [/toggle] [/columns]
